items.title: Question: custom primitives from specific fields in an EntitySet
items.body:
For example, my EntitySet has the fields `a` (numeric), `b` (numeric), `c` (numeric), `d` (categorical). and given the dummy primitive:

```python
from featuretools.primitives import make_trans_primitive
from featuretools.variable_types import Numeric

def dummy(x, y):
    return x / y

Dummy = make_trans_primitive(function=dummy, input_types=[Numeric, Numeric], return_type=Numeric)
```

This dummy primitive would be computed for every permutation of `a`, `b` and `c`? i.e. `(a, b)`, `(a, c)`, `(b, a)`, `(b, c)`, `(c, a)`, `(c, b)`. Is there any way to restrict that computation to `a` and `b`?

items.title: Deprecation warning using Week primitive with pandas 1.1.0 installed

labels.name: Good First Issue
labels.description: These issues are good for first time contributors to get started developing Featuretools

items.body:
In panadas version `1.1.0`, `Series.dt.weekofyear` and `Series.dt.week` have been deprecated. This results in a warning when using the `Week` transform primitive.

This primitive should be updated to prevent this warning. After updating, compatibility should be checked with older versions of pandas as well to determine if the pandas version specified in `requirements.txt` needs to be updated.

```
FutureWarning: Series.dt.weekofyear and Series.dt.week have been deprecated.  Please use Series.dt.isocalendar().week instead.
```

[Pandas documentation](https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/reference/api/pandas.Series.dt.week.html)

items.title: Built-in subtract_numeric primitive ignores certain variables
items.body:
### Bug/Feature Request Title
Built-in subtract_numeric primitive ignores certain variables

-----

featurestools version: 0.17.0
python version: Python 3.6.10

#### Bug/Feature Request Description
1. Prepare the entityset 
```
data = {"index": [0, 1, 2],
        "a": [1, -2, 3.8],
        "b": [4, 15, 6.2],
        "c": [2.3, 2, 0],
        "d": [-9, 0, np.nan]}

df = pd.DataFrame(data=data)

es = ft.EntitySet(id="es")
es = es.entity_from_dataframe(entity_id="test",
                              dataframe=df,
                              index="index")
```
2. Create a custom primitive for subtraction (which has the same function definition as built-in primitive `subtract_numeric`)
```
def basic_subtract(subtrahend, minuend):
    return np.subtract(subtrahend, minuend)

BasicSubtract = make_trans_primitive(function=basic_subtract, input_types=[Numeric, Numeric], return_type=Numeric)
```
3. DFS
```
feature_matrix, feature_defs = ft.dfs(entityset=es, target_entity="test",
                                      trans_primitives=[
                                                        "subtract_numeric",
                                                        BasicSubtract
                                                        ], 
                                      primitive_options={
                                            "subtract_numeric": [{  
                                                          "include_variables": {"test": ["a", "d"]}
                                                        },
                                                        {
                                                            "include_variables": {"test": ["b", "c"]}
                                                        }],
                                            BasicSubtract: [{  
                                                          "include_variables": {"test": ["a", "d"]}
                                                        },
                                                        {
                                                            "include_variables": {"test": ["b", "c"]}
                                                        }],
                                            
                                      },
                                      max_depth = 2,
                                      )
```

#### Actual Output
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/36015810/88023572-43baac80-caff-11ea-88fc-353ae1ea8a9e.png)


#### Expected Output
Both `subtract_numeric` and `BasicSubtract` should create 4 features while `subtract_numeric` ignores variable `d`.

items.title: Warn user if supplying wrong input to Entity.delete_variables()

labels.name: Good First Issue
labels.description: These issues are good for first time contributors to get started developing Featuretools

items.body:
If a user calls `Entity.delete_variables()` and passes in a string variable name instead of a list of variable names, the method attempts to loop over all the characters in the supplied string and fails with an error that is not too helpful for the user to understand what happened. We should update this method to raise a `TypeError` with an appropriate message if a string is supplied instead of a list.

Example:
```
from featuretools.tests.testing_utils import make_ecommerce_entityset

es = make_ecommerce_entityset()
es['customers'].delete_variables('age')

Traceback (most recent call last):
KeyError: 'Variable: a not found in entity'
```

items.title: TimeSince primitive works only with DatetimeTimeIndex type
items.body:
### TimeSince primitive works only with DatetimeTimeIndex type


#### Bug/Feature Request Description

Transform primitive ``time_since`` should match all Datetime variables:
https://github.com/FeatureLabs/featuretools/blob/8693e5cd438a065fc64a1e1535e74ec54ab85cad/featuretools/primitives/standard/transform_primitive.py#L389-L390

However, it only matches those whose type is DatetimeTimeIndex as the following example reflects.

```python
import featuretools as ft
import featuretools.variable_types as vtypes
from featuretools.tests.testing_utils import make_ecommerce_entityset

es = make_ecommerce_entityset()
target_entity = es["customers"]
# Calculate all datetime-like vars
datetime_vars = [id for id,t in target_entity.variable_types.items() if issubclass(t, vtypes.Datetime)]
print(len(datetime_vars))  # should print 4

# Apply time_since only to 'customers' entity
primitive_options={
    'time_since': {
        'include_entities': ['customers'],
    }
}

fm, fl = ft.dfs(
    target_entity="customers",
    entityset=es,
    trans_primitives=["time_since"],
    agg_primitives=[],
    max_depth=1,
    primitive_options=primitive_options
)

matched_columns = [c for c in fm.columns if c.startswith('TIME_SINCE')]
# Should output 4 columns corresponding to all Datetime vars
# but only matches the one whose type is DatetimeTimeIndex instead
print(len(matched_columns))  

```

This happens because only the first set of input types is selected when there is more than one:

https://github.com/FeatureLabs/featuretools/blob/8693e5cd438a065fc64a1e1535e74ec54ab85cad/featuretools/synthesis/deep_feature_synthesis.py#L561-L562

Nonetheless, later in the process all those features whose type is a subclass of the input_type are matched

https://github.com/FeatureLabs/featuretools/blob/8693e5cd438a065fc64a1e1535e74ec54ab85cad/featuretools/synthesis/deep_feature_synthesis.py#L749-L755

Therefore, we can solve this issue by simply using ``Datetime`` as ``time_since``'s input_type, since ``DatetimeTimeIndex`` is a subclass of the former. 



#### Output of ``featuretools.show_info()``

2020-07-03 19:36:57,089 featuretools - WARNING    Featuretools failed to load plugin nlp_primitives from library nlp_primitives. For a full stack trace, set logging to debug.
Featuretools version: 0.17.0
Featuretools installation directory: /mnt/c/Users/Montana/PycharmProjects/featuretools/featuretools

SYSTEM INFO
-----------

items.title: Invalid instance ID causes TypeError (non-category item)
items.body:
### Invalid instance ID causes TypeError (non-category item)
- Before 0.17.0, if an invalid instance ID was passed to `calculate_feature_matrix`, there would no error and the feature matrix would calculate.
- However, some modification in https://github.com/FeatureLabs/featuretools/commit/f21606a6961e4b9ad2f50d9340d0de712a594e33 resulted in a change where this no longer occures. Now an error shows up.
- Installing any featuretools version before f21606a6961e4b9ad2f50d9340d0de712a594e33 will fix the error. 

#### Expected Output
- `calculate_feature_matrix` is able to run with an invalid instance ID, and calculate the feature matrix accordingly. 

#### Steps to Reproduce
- Run `calculate_feature_matrix` with an invalid instance ID. **(Instance ID of 3 is invalid for ecommerce & customers entity)**

```python
import featuretools as ft
from featuretools.tests.testing_utils import make_ecommerce_entityset
from featuretools import dfs

es = make_ecommerce_entityset()
target_entity = 'customers'
instance_ids = [0, 1, 2, 3]
max_depth = 3
max_features = -1

features = dfs(entityset=es, target_entity=target_entity,
               max_depth=max_depth, features_only=True)

df = ft.calculate_feature_matrix(entityset=es,
                                 features=features,
                                 instance_ids=instance_ids)
```

items.title: Add dask (and koalas in future) as optional requirement
items.body:
In the code I see statements such as `import dask.dataframe as dd`, how does it behave when Dask is not installed?

Maybe we should use something like this https://stackoverflow.com/a/52826085 to handle cases where Dask is not installed.

I think we should also add add "dask" as "extras_require" in the setup.py file (see https://github.com/FeatureLabs/featuretools/blob/master/setup.py#L9) and remove it from install requirements, since not everybody needs Dask support.

The same approach should probably be used when Koalas dataframes support will be merged.

items.title: Inconsistencies when passing Dask dataframe for cutoff times
items.body:
There are some inconsistencies between `dfs` and `calculate_feature_matrix` in what happens if a Dask dataframe is passed in for cutoff times. In `dfs` a warning is raised and the Dask dataframe is computed and turned into a pandas dataframe. If `calculate_feature_matrix` is called directly with a Dask dataframe for cutoff times a `TypeError` is raised.

Recommended Fix: Remove error from `calculate_feature_matrix` and move warning from `dfs` to `calculate_feature_matrix`, so no matter which call is made, a warning will be raised followed by a compute call to convert the dataframe from Dask to pandas. The documentation should also be updated to clarify this detail as currently the documentation for Dask EntitySets indicates Dask cutoff time dataframes cannot be used at all.

items.title: Calculate feature matrix fails if target entity time index is 'time'
items.body:
With the changes from #969, `calculate_feature_matrix` now fails if the target entity's time index is named `'time'`, even if `cutoff_time` only contains the columns `instance_id` and `time`.
```python
df = pd.DataFrame({
    'id': range(4),
    'time': [datetime(2010, 1, 1),
             datetime(2011, 1, 1),
             datetime(2012, 1, 1), 
             datetime(2013, 1, 1)]
})

es = ft.EntitySet('test')
es.entity_from_dataframe('times', df, index='id', time_index='time')

ft.dfs('times', es)

>>> AttributeError: Cutoff time DataFrame cannot contain both a column named "time" and a column with the same name as the target entity time index
```

items.title: Docstring mismatch between dfs method and EntitySet

labels.name: Good First Issue
labels.description: These issues are good for first time contributors to get started developing Featuretools

items.body:
When creating an `EntitySet` by passing a list of entities and relationships, you can also optionally pass in the entity variable types as specified in the `EntitySet` docstring:

```
entities (dict[str -> tuple(pd.DataFrame, str, str)]): Dictionary of
    entities. Entries take the format
    {entity id -> (dataframe, id column, (time_column), (variable_types))}.
     Note that time_column and variable_types are optional.
```

The docstring for `ft.dfs` does not mention optional variable types:
```
entities (dict[str -> tuple(pd.DataFrame, str, str)]): Dictionary of
    entities. Entries take the format
    {entity id -> (dataframe, id column, (time_column))}.
```

The `EntitySet` docstring should include the type hint information for `variable_types` which is currently missing in the tuple. The `dfs` docstring should then be updated to match the `EntitySet` docstring for `entites`.

items.body: It would be super exciting to see recommendations for the primitives to be used for a certain type of dataset that FeatureTool is working upon.

items.title: Clean up dask-tmp folder and dask tests
items.body: We need to reorganize the dask tests (move them to relevant files) and remove the dask tmp folder / migrate its contents to more appropriate places

items.title: Add support for serializing/deserializing Dask EntitySets
items.body: Support for serializing a Dask EntitySet has been added but not deserializing one. Support for both should be added and functionality should be tested

items.title: Support EqualScalar and NotEqualScalar Primitives with Dask
items.body: The EqualScalar primitive currently has Dask related code, but the NotEqualScalar primitive does not. Both are currently marked as unsupported by Dask. Review these primitives to determine if they can be supported using code similar to that in EqualScalar.

items.title: Update ft.list_primitives() to identify Dask compatible primitives
items.body: To help users get a current list of primitives that work with Dask entitysets, we should update `ft.list_primitives()` to add a boolean column to the output which indicates whether the primitive will work with Dask or not.

items.title: Refactor handling of cutoff times when a single value or no value is passed to DFS
items.body:
If the user supplies a single cutoff time to DFS or if no cutoff time is supplied, the current code in `calculate_feature_matrix` generates a new cutoff_time dataframe to use in downstream processing.  This approach is inefficient for large datasets as a large dataframe is being generated and the cutoff time column contains only one unique value which is equal to the cutoff time value supplied by the user.

The code should be refactored to eliminate the need to generate this intermediate dataframe when cutoff values are identical for all instances. 

Refactoring will also resolve issue #907 which cases slow run times when using Dask entities for DFS.

items.title: Mention how to install featuretools for development in contributing.md
items.body: This doc should outline how to install featuretools for development or link to how to install it

items.title: Refactor infer_variable_types for Dask entities
items.body:
In `infer_variable_types()` in `entity_utils.py` there is a `len()` call to get the dataframe length. This call causes the entity creation process to be slow for Dask dataframes. Additionally, this function also contains a `.compute()` call on the sample dataframe, but this computed sample dataframe is never used for Dask as the user must specify the datatypes for Dask entities.

This code could be refactored with these changes:
- Only perform the `len()` call if the input dataframe is a Pandas dataframe
- Remove the code block that computes the sample_df if the input df is a Dask dataframe as this sample is never used for a Dask entity
- Revert the code for selecting the sample to match the code on `master`. This code was updated to work with Dask dataframes, but since `sample_df` is no longer needed for Dask, this can be reverted to its original form.

items.title: Raise error if approximate parameter is used for DFS with a Dask entityset
items.body: Running `ft.dfs()` with the `approximate` parameter on a Dask entityset is not currently supported. An appropriate error should be raised if the user attempts to use this parameter with a Dask entityset.

items.title: Raise error if training_window parameter is used for DFS with Dask entityset
items.body: Running `ft.dfs()` with the `training_window` parameter on a Dask entityset is not currently supported. An appropriate error should be raised if the user attempts to use this parameter with a Dask entityset.

items.title: Raise error if using Dask feature matrix with ft.encode_features()
items.body: Running `ft.encode_features()` on a Dask dataframe does not currently work. Eventually `encode_features()` should be updated to work with a Dask feature matrix (issue #899), but for the initial release for Dask we should raise an error if a user attempts to pass a Dask dataframe to `encode_features()`.

items.title: Create clean example for using Dask with the Instacart dataset
items.body:
We currently have two scripts in the `dask-entity` branch for running the Instacart dataset with Dask. One script requires a separate preprocessing script to be run and contains unused machine learning code. The second script does not use compose and has not been tested recently with recent dask related code updates. 

These examples should be cleaned up to have either a single script or a notebook that explains how to use Dask to generate a feature matrix from this dataset.

- The keys of this dictionary should all be lowercase. To fix this, we should look at changing the Unknown variable type so it has correct name, like so:
```python
class Unknown(Variable):
    type_string = "unknown"
```
- In addition we **may** want to have a clear key to Name transition. The following need to fixed EmailAddress, FilePath, IPAddress, SubRegionCode because they don't fit the majority lowercase to CamelCase transition. 


#### Expected Output
```python
{'unknown': featuretools.variable_types.variable.Unknown}
```

items.title: Support passing strings to variable_types in DFS
items.body:
### Support passing strings to variable_types in DFS

#### Feature Request Description
- One of the useful things that we do for passing primitives to DFS is allowing the user to specify the strings.
- We should also allow this functionality for variable_types. Instead of specifying the Python classes, a user can pass the names of the variable type. For example:
```json
{
  "cancelled": "boolean",
  "country": "categorical",
  "customer_name": "categorical",
  "description": "categorical",
  "order_date": "datetime",
  "order_id": "numeric",
  "product_id": "categorical",
  "quantity": "numeric",
  "total": "numeric",
  "unit_price": "numeric"
}
```
- These may need to be all be lowercase, just like the primitives.

items.title: Parameterize Inclusive Cutoff Times
items.body:
Data at cutoff times are currently included in feature calculations. We can make this a parameter to provide users the option to exclude the data.

#### Software Design
The parameter `include_cutoff_time` would be added in `dfs` and `calculate_feature_matrix`  to control whether data at cutoff times are included in feature calculations.

```python
ft.dfs(
    ...
    include_cutoff_time=True,
)
```

When using cutoff times with training windows, the training window start time (left endpoint) should be excluded from feature calculations when the cutoff time (right endpoint) is included. This will avoid overlap from consecutive training windows. Similarly, the training window start time should be included when the cutoff time is excluded.

#### Test Cases

There should be test cases that check feature calculations when:

- A training window is not used and cutoff times are inclusive.
- A training window is not used and cutoff times are exclusive.
- A training window is used and cutoff times are inclusive.
- A training window is used and cutoff times are exclusive.

items.title: Cleanly close tqdm instance
items.body:
With `conda create -n ft 'featuretools<0.14.0' tqdm ipykernel`:

```python
#from tqdm.auto import tqdm
from tqdm import tqdm
import pandas as pd
from random import random
import warnings

with warnings.catch_warnings():
    warnings.filterwarnings('ignore', category=FutureWarning)
    tqdm.pandas()

df = pd.DataFrame((random() for _ in range(10)) for _ in range(int(1e6)))

try:
    df.progress_apply(lambda x: x**x ** (1/x) ** x ** (1/x) ** x ** (1/x))
except KeyboardInterrupt:
    print("finished with %d instances left" % len(tqdm._instances))
```
```
60%|██████    | 6/10 [00:02<00:01,  2.77it/s]
finished with 0 instances left
```
```python
#from tqdm.auto import tqdm
from tqdm import tqdm
import featuretools as ft

es = ft.demo.load_mock_customer(return_entityset=True)
cutoff_time = es['transactions'].df[["transaction_id", "transaction_time"]]

try:
    ft.dfs(entityset=es, target_entity='transactions', cutoff_time=cutoff_time, verbose=True)
except KeyboardInterrupt:
    print("finished with %d instances left" % len(tqdm._instances))
```
```
Built 33 features
Elapsed: 00:02 | Progress:   6%|▌         finished with 1 instances left
Elapsed: 00:02 | Progress:   6%|▌         
```

So `tqdm.pandas` works as expected but `featuretools` doesn't.

Looks like `featuretools` may have some error handling. My guess is your custom function which you're handing to `pandas` will itself catch the error and not let it propagate to `tqdm`. If you're doing your own error handling then it's your responsibility to clean up everything, including but not limited to `tqdm`. You'd really need to `close()` the `tqdm` instance rather than hackily clearing the whole internal `_instances` set:

https://github.com/tqdm/tqdm/blob/5e8978909c639bc20f58bf877e66cc6a0b9fb5bf/tqdm/std.py#L766-L767

_Originally posted by @casperdcl in https://github.com/FeatureLabs/featuretools/pull/932#issuecomment-622453513_

items.title: Functionality - Creating custom primitive using classes
items.body: Is there a way to create a custom primitive from a class of functions? For example - If I have class A with function B, C and D, can I define the class as an agg primitive to call all the functions? That way all functions need not have its own custom primitive and just the class can be defined as so.

items.title: Review and remove unnecessary code related to Dask
items.body:
With the current list of unsupported primitives and some of the items that are now out of scope for the initial Dask implementation, there is significant amount of old code in the code base that may not be needed for the initial release.

In particular, the following aggregation primitives have Dask related code but are not currently supported for the initial release: Mode, NMostCommon, Median, Skew, Entropy.

There is also a large block of code that is not being executed in `FeatureSetCalculator._calculate_agg_features()`.

In addition to those issues, test coverage reports should be reviewed to confirm that all new Dask related code is tested properly, and that all other unnecessary Dask code has been removed.

items.title: Refactor usage of update_feature_columns() to improve performance
items.body:
Currently for transform primitives, a call is made to `update_feature_columns()` for each feature column. This results in repeated column assignment using `df[col] = value`. This is problematic for Dask if there are a large number of features as it is both slow and creates a complicated task graph. A better approach is to assign all of the new columns in a single call using `df.assign(**new_cols_dict)`. Limited testing shows the approaches are essentially equivalent when working with pandas dataframes.

The current code should be refactored to use `df.assign()` in place of `df[col] = value`.

items.title: Lookahead(cheating) issue
items.body:
### duplicated counting issue


#### Bug/Feature Request Description
I will quote my stack overflow question and answer: https://stackoverflow.com/a/61261300/3595632.
The problem is that feature generated by `dfs()` count the same value that `cutoff_time` Dataframe already count:  When Jeff calculating `lt`, he already counted the amount of "2012-03-01" of store 0 for the aggregated amount of `cutoff_time = "2012-03-01"(store 0)` (and I think this makes sense). So, 1 month amount aggregation period: 2012-03-01 ~ 2012-03-31, **March**, 2012.
Let's see `SUM(sales.amount)` column value of (`store_id = 0` & `2012-03-01` cutoff time). The value is 44 by adding up the amounts of 2012-02-05, 2012-02-10, and """2012-03-01"""!!!. It counts """2012-03-01""" here again, which is a sort of cheating and look-ahead bias.

2012-03-01 is March, not February. We must predict 1 month total amount of March, using ONLY February information.... 
 

#### Expected Output
I think that `SUM(sales.amount)` column value of (`store_id = 0` & `2012-03-01` cutoff time) must be 16 + 15 = 31, excluding 2012-03-01 amount.

items.title: Dask Entity.set_time_index doesn't change dtype
items.body: The Dask implementation of `Entity.set_time_index` currently skips changing the dtype of the new time index to either a `DatetimeTimeIndex` or a `NumericTimeIndex`, resulting in dtype errors when trying to use the entity's time_index.

items.title: [discussion] Improvements to the Timedelta class
items.body:
Today I wanted to make a `Timedelta` that used the pandas`MonthEnd` offset, but that isn't one of the supported units.

I was able to make one anyway though:
```
offset = pd.tseries.offsets.MonthEnd(1)
td = ft.Timedelta("2 years", delta_obj=offset)
```

I passed this to `DFS` as the `training_window` and the resulting features matched a training window using up to the end of the last month's worth of data, not two years' worth.  When creating the `Timedelta`, supplying a string or unit + value combination was required, even though these inputs were not used.

This doesn't seem ideal.  Some ideas I had for changes we can make
* Should we add the ability to create a timedelta by passing in just the `delta_obj`?
* Should we perform some validation that the `delta_obj` and `value` match, if both are provided?
* Should we add more supported units?

I think we can use this issue for discussion and break this up into separate issues if necessary.

items.title: Run full unit tests with dask
items.body:
* How do we run the test suite twice (w/ dask and pandas) without duplicated code?
* We can mark certain tests as expect to fail
* We should also be able to repeat easily as we support other types of dataframes like Koalas or cuDF

items.title: Primitives that are unsupported in Dask
Review usage of len() call in Entityset.add_relationship()
items.body: A `len()` call is used in `Entityset.add_relationship()` in an `if` statement to check if the child dataframe is empty. In the current dask implementation this code is commented out, and this did not cause any existing tests to fail. This code should be reviewed and updated if this check is needed.

items.title: Remove .compute() call in Entity.set_index()
items.body: There is a .compute() call in `Entity.set_index()` in the current featuretools Dask implementation. This call is used when `unique` is set to `True`. This should be reviewed and updated so this call is no longer required. Perhaps this check should be skipped for Dask entities, along with a warning/error being raised if a Dask entity is used while `unique` is set to `True`.

items.title: Remove .compute() call in update_feature_columns for Dask dataframes
items.body: Currently `update_feature_columns()` in `feature_set_calculator.py` relies on a `.compute()` call along with creation of a pandas dataframe to merge the new column into the dataframe when working with Dask. This should be updated for improved performance.

items.title: Remove .compute() call in FeatureSetCalculator._calculate_features_for_entity
items.body: In `FeatureSetCalculator._calculate_features_for_entity()` a `.compute()` call is used if `need_full_entity` is `True`. A test for this should be created and the code should be updated to use a `merge` operation instead of an `isin()` check for Dask dataframes since a Dask dataframe cannot be passed to `isin()` currently.

items.title: Raise error if cutoff times are supplied as a Dask dataframe

items.title: get_names() and get_name() do not return the same value if num_of_output features is 1
items.body:
#### Bug Request Description
- `get_names` and `get_name` are two functions we use to get the feature name (corresponding to the 
column names in the feature matrix).
- If the `number_output_features` is 1 for a feature, they should return the same thing (a list with 1 item, that is the same as the `get_name`. 
- Related [issue](792) **But not the same**

#### Current Behavior
```python
import featuretools as ft
es = ft.demo.load_mock_customer(return_entityset=True)
_, feature_defs = ft.dfs(entityset=es,
                                      target_entity="customers",
                                      agg_primitives=[],
                                      trans_primitives=["month"],
                                      max_depth=1)
print(feature_defs[1].get_name())
print(feature_defs[1].get_names())
```

##### Current Output
```python
 'MONTH(join_date)'
['MONTH(join_date)[0]']
```
#### Expected Output
```python
 'MONTH(join_date)'
['MONTH(join_date)']
```

items.title: Drop Python 3.5 Support
items.body:
Python 3.5 is reaching its end-of-life (September 13, 2020), and some libraries Featuretools depends on (Pandas, Dask, etc.) no longer support python 3.5 in their latest releases.

We plan on supporting Python 3.5 for the next release of Featuretools and dropping support after that.  Please let us know if you have any problems with this plan.

items.title: Add warning if entry point plugin fails to load
items.body:
There is a 'featuretools_plugin' [entrypoint](https://packaging.python.org/specifications/entry-points/) that allows other libraries to be imported as if they were part of featuretools.  For example, functions from the autonormalize library can be imported from the `featuretools.autonormalize` module location.

When Featuretools is imported, it sets up these entrypoints.  However, if an exception occurs while loading an entrypoint, the exception is silenced.  As an example, if pip failed to install the other library cleanly due to conflicting dependency versions, the entrypoint would not work.

While reporting the full stack trace of the exception could be too much info, raising a warning like "Failed to load featuretools plugin from autonormalize library" would communicate that something is wrong.

items.title: How can I deal with memory problem?
items.body:
### Bug/Feature Request Title

I got a bunch of WARNING messages during `dfs` process. Here is the code:

```
features= ft.dfs(
    entityset=es,
    target_entity='stores',
    cutoff_time=data_df[['store_id', 'cutoff_time', '3month_amount_from_cutoff_time']],
    verbose=1,
    cutoff_time_in_index=True,
    n_jobs=16,
    max_depth=2,
    ignore_variables={
        'sales':['sale_id'],
    },
    agg_primitives=[
        "sum", "std", "max","skew", "min", "mean", "median", "count", "percent_true", "num_unique", "mode", "trend", "time_since_last", "time_since_first",
        "first", "last", "entropy", "avg_time_between",
        "n_most_common",
        # "any", "all", "num_true",
    ],
    groupby_trans_primitives=[
        'cum_mean', 'cum_sum', 'cum_min', 'cum_max', 'cum_count',
        'year', 'month',
        'diff', 'haversine', 'is_null', 'percentile',
        'time_since', 'time_since_previous',
    ],
    trans_primitives=[],
    chunk_size=200,
)

# data_df.shape => (61034, 101)
# dataframe in es's shape
#    - es['stores'].shape => (1967, 6)
#    - es['sales'].shape => (6556613, 6)
```


And WARNING messages I've got:
```
...
...
distributed.worker - WARNING - Memory use is high but worker has no data to store to disk.  Perhaps some other process is leaking memory?  Process memory: 12.89 GB -- Worker memory limit: 16.54 GB
distributed.worker - WARNING - Memory use is high but worker has no data to store to disk.  Perhaps some other process is leaking memory?  Process memory: 11.98 GB -- Worker memory limit: 16.54 GB

distributed.worker - WARNING - Memory use is high but worker has no data to store to disk.  Perhaps some other process is leaking memory?  Process memory: 12.52 GB -- Worker memory limit: 16.54 GB
...
...

```

-----


#### Bug/Feature Request Description
These WARNING start to show up around 45% in progress bar. I know these are WARNING, but problem is that it finally makes `dfs` stop running after a few hours later...(raise errors!)

I have enough memory (256GB), the number of cpu (64) but I don't see why it still requires more memory despite of its small memory size. 



And when finally `dfs` is stopped, error messages is like this:
```
distributed.nanny - WARNING - Worker exceeded 95% memory budget. Restarting

Worker.execute() done, defined at /data/miniconda3/lib/python3.7/site-packages/distributed/worker.py:2391> exception=KeyError('EntitySet-dcc40d75cfac8a5e5765e5bba8aeeb7a')>)
```
